Introduction

Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a severe anxiety response to a life-threatening event.  It is characterized by reexperience of trauma, a negative mood, avoidance, and hyperarousal.  Symptoms must persist for more than a month and cause significant functional impairment.

Epidemiology and risk factors



The estimated lifetime prevalence of PTSD is 2%, and the majority of people exposed to a traumatic event do not develop PTSD.  PTSD is more common in women, which may be partly related to a higher likelihood of exposure to interpersonal trauma (eg, rape, intimate partner violence).



Risk factors that may increase the development of PTSD after trauma exposure include:



  • Severity of trauma (eg, significant physical injury, prolonged duration of exposure)
  • Close proximity to trauma (eg, self vs relative/witness)
  • Dissociative response during trauma
  • Limited social support
  • Previous trauma exposures
  • History of adverse childhood events (eg, abuse, neglect)
  • Personal and/or family history of psychiatric conditions

Pathogenesis



The development of PTSD after trauma exposure is not fully understood.  However, there may be an association with a dysregulation of neurotransmitters:  increased norepinephrine levels, resulting in an elevated sympathetic response (eg, increased heart rate and blood pressure, startle response), and decreased GABA and serotonin activity.  Structural and functional changes in brain structure, including decreased hippocampal volume and overactivation of the amygdala (emotion processing and fear response), have also been associated with PTSD.

Clinical presentation



PTSD can affect people of any age (symptoms can be seen in children as young as age 1) and can present in many different ways.  Most patients reexperience the trauma in some way (eg, trauma-related nightmares, intrusive memories of the event) and have a high level of reactivity to trauma cues (eg, panic attacks, startle response).  Somatic symptoms (eg, sleep disturbances, headaches, heart palpitations) are common.  In young children, frightening dreams and reenactment of the trauma through play can occur.  For some patients, symptom onset may be delayed by months or, sometimes, years.

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of PTSD, the following criteria must be met:



  • Exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violation in â‰¥1 of the following ways:

    • Directly experiencing a traumatic event (eg, sexual violence, earthquake)
    • Witnessing, in person, the event as it occurred to others (eg, witnessing a fatal vehicle collision)
    • Learning that the event occurred to a close family member or friend
    • Experiencing repeated or extreme exposure to details of a traumatic event (eg, pathologist performing autopsies on severely injured bodies)
  • â‰¥1 intrusion symptoms associated with the traumatic event:
    • Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories
    • Recurrent distressing dreams that relate to the trauma through content or affect (frightening dreams not directly about the trauma)
    • Dissociative reactions experienced as if the trauma were recurring (eg, flashbacks)
    • Intense emotional distress in response to trauma cues
    • Marked physiological reactions in response to trauma cues (eg, dyspnea while watching a film of a car crash)
  • Persistent avoidance of trauma reminders with 1 or both of the following:
    • Efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings related to the traumatic event (eg, excessive alcohol use)
    • Efforts to avoid cues that cause distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings (eg, not going out at night after being robbed)
  • Negative alterations in thoughts and mood associated with the trauma with â‰¥2 of the following:
    • Inability to remember important aspects of the traumatic event (dissociative amnesia)
    • Persistent and exaggerated negative beliefs about self, others, or the world (eg, "No place is safe," "I don't deserve anything good")
    • Persistent, distorted thoughts about the cause or consequences of the trauma, resulting in self-blame or blaming of others (eg, "It's all my fault")
    • Persistent negative emotional state (eg, guilt, anger, fear)
    • Diminished interest or participation in significant activities
    • Feelings of detachment or estrangement from others
    • Persistent inability to experience positive emotions (eg, unable to feel happiness or excitement)
  • Marked alterations in reactivity associated with the trauma with â‰¥2 of the following:
    • Irritability and angry outbursts (may involve physical or verbal aggression toward people or objects)
    • Reckless or self-destructive behavior (eg, unsafe sex, substance use)
    • Hypervigilance (eg, staying near an exit, scanning the room for signs of danger)
    • Exaggerated startle response (eg, jumpiness upon hearing phone ringing or car honking)
    • Concentration difficulties
    • Sleep disturbance

Differential diagnosis



  • Acute stress disorder (ASD):  also characterized by an impairing stress response resulting from actual/threatened death or injury.  However, ASD symptoms last a month or less, as opposed to the more chronic nature of PTSD (symptom duration >1 month).
  • Adjustment disorder:  also consists of an acute response to a stressor.  However, the stressor can be of any severity (eg, moving, divorce) and is not typically associated with intrusive distressing memories or avoidance behaviors.
  • Major depressive disorder (MDD):  may also develop after trauma exposure and includes negative emotions, sleep disturbances, and concentration difficulties.  However, intrusion symptoms, avoidance of trauma stimuli, and hypervigilance are not associated with MDD.  PTSD can coincide with MDD, in which case both should be diagnosed.
  • Psychotic disorders:  associated with a higher risk for violent victimization and can also include paranoia/hypervigilance as well as perceptual disturbances that may appear similar to flashbacks and pseudohallucinatory experiences (hearing thoughts spoken out loud) in PTSD.  However, disorganized speech and behavior and a lack of insight are not characteristic of PTSD.

Management



First-line treatment of PTSD typically involves trauma-focused psychotherapy, which can include trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) therapy:



  • Trauma-focused CBT:  consists of increasing coping skills, identifying and reframing cognitive distortions (eg, thinking the world is unsafe), and exposing patients to trauma cues in a controlled manner.
  • EMDR:  involves accessing distressing memories of a trauma (eg, a vivid image or bodily sensation) while engaging in bilateral stimulation (eg, moving the eyes laterally), and then reprocessing the memory with positive associations.  This results in reduced emotion and intensity related to the memory (desensitization).


Pharmacotherapy may also be considered first-line treatment for patients who have comorbid anxiety or depressive disorders or for those who decline or do not have access to psychotherapy.  Treatment with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors is preferred due to their tolerability and efficacy.



For significant sleep disturbances and/or nightmares, augmentation with prazosin (alpha-adrenergic receptor blocker) may be effective in some patients to reduce nightmare frequency and improve sleep.



PTSD is associated with an elevated suicide risk and warrants screening for suicidal ideation, assessment of risk factors, and safety planning.  Comorbid conditions (MDD, bipolar disorder, and substance use disorders) are common and require screening and treatment.

Prognosis



PTSD is considered a chronic disorder; about a third of patients experience a full recovery within a year of diagnosis, and another third of patients continue to be symptomatic 10 years later.  Positive prognostic factors include early engagement with treatment, strong social support, lack of comorbid psychiatric conditions, and no coinciding substance use disorders.

Summary



Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) (
